Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)_1:
Description 1:
    A 14-year-old female patient, with a known history of Type 1 diabetes mellitus, presented with a complex set of symptoms. The patient's Blood Glucose Level (BGL) was markedly elevated at 15.5 mmol/L, and she exhibited an altered conscious state, marked by irritability and lethargy. Additionally, the presence of ketosis, dehydration, and vomiting was observed. The patient's condition was further complicated by a severe headache. It is noteworthy that the young patient had experienced incontinence and thermal instability. Given the context of inadequate insulin in an adolescent with known diabetes, as well as the combination of these symptoms, a comprehensive diagnostic evaluation is imperative.
Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)_2:
Description 2:
    A 10-year-old male child, without a prior history of diabetes, was brought to the emergency department with concerning symptoms. The patient presented with a Blood Glucose Level (BGL) of 17.2 mmol/L, indicating hyperglycemia. The altered conscious state was evident as the child appeared irritable and lethargic. Moreover, ketosis and vomiting were noted, along with signs of dehydration. The patient's parents reported a recent illness preceding the onset of these symptoms. Given the first presentation of Type 1 diabetes mellitus in a child, coupled with the history of recent illness, the diagnostic assessment and initiation of management are crucial.
Diabetic Ketoacidosis (DKA)_3:
Description 3:
    A 28-year-old male patient, known to have Type 1 diabetes mellitus, presented with a constellation of distressing symptoms. The patient's Blood Glucose Level (BGL) was substantially elevated at 19.0 mmol/L. He exhibited an altered conscious state, characterized by irritability and lethargy, in addition to the presence of ketosis and vomiting. The patient reported a severe headache and displayed signs of dehydration. Notably, he experienced incontinence and thermal instability. Given the context of inadequate insulin, as well as the recurrence of these symptoms in an adult with known diabetes, an urgent diagnostic evaluation and management plan are imperative.
